values.description:
This is a workaround to keep sdformat-sdf package (sdf1.5 implementation) backwards compatible with version 2.x. See issue #102 for more details.

The add of iterations [seems to be the only change done to sdf1.5](#!/osrf/sdformat/annotate/052a15093457a2c4e55092d2389ce869f59d2107/sdf/1.5/state.sdf?at=default) to the file since it was created.

BTW: I've created the sdf3 branch, according to [new gazebo branch naming](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/issues/1400/proposal-for-naming-release-branches), to release 3.x from there.
values.title: Keep backwards compat in sdf1.5 by using int instead of uint64_t (issue #102)

summary.raw:
This is a workaround to keep sdformat-sdf package (sdf1.5 implementation) backwards compatible with version 2.x. See issue #102 for more details.

The add of iterations [seems to be the only change done to sdf1.5](#!/osrf/sdformat/annotate/052a15093457a2c4e55092d2389ce869f59d2107/sdf/1.5/state.sdf?at=default) to the file since it was created.

BTW: I've created the sdf3 branch, according to [new gazebo branch naming](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/issues/1400/proposal-for-naming-release-branches), to release 3.x from there.
summary.html:
This is a workaround to keep sdformat-sdf package (sdf1.5 implementation) backwards compatible with version 2.x. See issue #102 for more details.

The add of iterations seems to be the only change done to sdf1.5 to the file since it was created.

BTW: I've created the sdf3 branch, according to new gazebo branch naming, to release 3.x from there.

values.description:
On multi-architecture systems architecture-dependent files are installed
to different prefixes which include the triplet of the host architecture
they are for (e.g.  /usr/x86_64-pc-linux-gnu and
/usr/i686-pc-linux-gnu), but files independent of the architecture are
not supposed to be installed under that prefix but to /usr/share/.

Using CMAKE_INSTALL_FULL_DATAROOTDIR instead of hard-coding
CMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX/share allows installing files according to that
layout
values.title: Install SDF files to CMAKE_INSTALL_FULL_DATAROOTDIR

summary.raw:
On multi-architecture systems architecture-dependent files are installed
to different prefixes which include the triplet of the host architecture
they are for (e.g.  /usr/x86_64-pc-linux-gnu and
/usr/i686-pc-linux-gnu), but files independent of the architecture are
not supposed to be installed under that prefix but to /usr/share/.

Using CMAKE_INSTALL_FULL_DATAROOTDIR instead of hard-coding
CMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX/share allows installing files according to that
layout
summary.html:
On multi-architecture systems architecture-dependent files are installed to different prefixes which include the triplet of the host architecture they are for (e.g. /usr/x86_64-pc-linux-gnu and /usr/i686-pc-linux-gnu), but files independent of the architecture are not supposed to be installed under that prefix but to /usr/share/.

Using CMAKE_INSTALL_FULL_DATAROOTDIR instead of hard-coding CMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX/share allows installing files according to that layout

values.description:
It was incoherent to have default `patch_radius` as 0 but default `surface_radius` as infinity. 

Since `patch_radius = sqrt(surface_radius * depth)`, the different default values would have opposite behaviours.
values.title: Torsional friction default surface radius not infinity

summary.raw:
It was incoherent to have default `patch_radius` as 0 but default `surface_radius` as infinity. 

Since `patch_radius = sqrt(surface_radius * depth)`, the different default values would have opposite behaviours.
summary.html:
It was incoherent to have default patch_radius as 0 but default surface_radius as infinity.

Since patch_radius = sqrt(surface_radius * depth), the different default values would have opposite behaviours.

values.description:
* implement collision_blobs similar to visual_blobs

previously, if you have extensions that you want to pass into `<collision>` from urdf extensions, you'll have to do something like this:

~~~
<gazebo reference="link">
  <mu>1.5</mu>
</gazebo>
~~~
and the parser (`parser_urdf.cc`) will have to special case `mu` for link, and pass it through into collision element.  The new approach is similar to what visual extension supports right now, i.e.
~~~
<gazebo reference="link">
  <collision>
    <friction>
      <ode>
        <mu>1.5</mu>
      </ode>
    </friction>
  </collision>
</gazebo>
~~~
And the entire `<collision>` block in the extension is copied into the resulting sdf collision block verbatim.

This allows us to add anything in the urdf extension without having to special case every property (e.g. `mu`, `mu2`, etc.), update parser and re-release sdformat when a new collision extension is needed.  The old style of visual and collision extension parameter assignment should be deprecated.

* refactor code further for collision blobs. copy changes for visual blobs. added / clarified lots of comments everywhere.

* add detailed comment on changes from impact of urdfdom_headers 0.2.x to 0.3.x migration -> mesh group removal.
values.title: Collision_blobs

summary.raw:
* implement collision_blobs similar to visual_blobs

previously, if you have extensions that you want to pass into `<collision>` from urdf extensions, you'll have to do something like this:

~~~
<gazebo reference="link">
  <mu>1.5</mu>
</gazebo>
~~~
and the parser (`parser_urdf.cc`) will have to special case `mu` for link, and pass it through into collision element.  The new approach is similar to what visual extension supports right now, i.e.
~~~
<gazebo reference="link">
  <collision>
    <friction>
      <ode>
        <mu>1.5</mu>
      </ode>
    </friction>
  </collision>
</gazebo>
~~~
And the entire `<collision>` block in the extension is copied into the resulting sdf collision block verbatim.

This allows us to add anything in the urdf extension without having to special case every property (e.g. `mu`, `mu2`, etc.), update parser and re-release sdformat when a new collision extension is needed.  The old style of visual and collision extension parameter assignment should be deprecated.

* refactor code further for collision blobs. copy changes for visual blobs. added / clarified lots of comments everywhere.

* add detailed comment on changes from impact of urdfdom_headers 0.2.x to 0.3.x migration -> mesh group removal.
summary.html:
• implement collision_blobs similar to visual_blobs

previously, if you have extensions that you want to pass into <collision> from urdf extensions, you'll have to do something like this:

<gazebo reference="link">
  <mu>1.5</mu>
</gazebo>

and the parser (parser_urdf.cc) will have to special case mu for link, and pass it through into collision element. The new approach is similar to what visual extension supports right now, i.e.

<gazebo reference="link">
  <collision>
    <friction>
      <ode>
        <mu>1.5</mu>
      </ode>
    </friction>
  </collision>
</gazebo>

And the entire <collision> block in the extension is copied into the resulting sdf collision block verbatim.

This allows us to add anything in the urdf extension without having to special case every property (e.g. mu, mu2, etc.), update parser and re-release sdformat when a new collision extension is needed. The old style of visual and collision extension parameter assignment should be deprecated.

  • refactor code further for collision blobs. copy changes for visual blobs. added / clarified lots of comments everywhere.

  • add detailed comment on changes from impact of urdfdom_headers 0.2.x to 0.3.x migration -> mesh group removal.

values.description:
@eltehupkes reported a memory leak in the `sdf::Element` class in #104 with an example program. I converted his example to a gtest, and I tried something new for measuring memory usage. In gazebo, we have some platform-specific code for getting memory usage on Linux and OS X, but I decided to try using the python [psutil](https://pypi.python.org/pypi/psutil/) module, which is a cross-platform way to get system statistics, like memory usage.

To fix the memory leak, I used a weak pointer. I checked [API/ABI](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/API_ABI%20checker/job/sdformat-any_to_any-abichecker-vivid-amd64/7/API_ABI_report/) and it is fine.

A brief summary of the changes:

* Use find_package to look for python in order to run the `check_test_ran.py` script (similar to [ign-math pull request 62](https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-math/pull-requests/62/fixes-for-compiling-and-running-tests-on/diff))
* Find python module `psutil` to get memory info, using a cmake function copied from catkin
* Add memory leak test that uses python psutil
* Fix memory leak with weak pointer
* Simplify `~Element` destructor

CI status:

* [passes on jenkins trusty](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/sdformat/job/sdformat-any-devel-trusty-amd64/18/)
* [passes on drone](https://drone.io/bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/945)

psutil isn't installed for the homebrew or windows jenkins jobs, though the test passes on my mac laptop
values.title: Fix shared pointer reference loop in Element and memory leak (#104)

summary.raw:
@eltehupkes reported a memory leak in the `sdf::Element` class in #104 with an example program. I converted his example to a gtest, and I tried something new for measuring memory usage. In gazebo, we have some platform-specific code for getting memory usage on Linux and OS X, but I decided to try using the python [psutil](https://pypi.python.org/pypi/psutil/) module, which is a cross-platform way to get system statistics, like memory usage.

To fix the memory leak, I used a weak pointer. I checked [API/ABI](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/API_ABI%20checker/job/sdformat-any_to_any-abichecker-vivid-amd64/7/API_ABI_report/) and it is fine.

A brief summary of the changes:

* Use find_package to look for python in order to run the `check_test_ran.py` script (similar to [ign-math pull request 62](https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-math/pull-requests/62/fixes-for-compiling-and-running-tests-on/diff))
* Find python module `psutil` to get memory info, using a cmake function copied from catkin
* Add memory leak test that uses python psutil
* Fix memory leak with weak pointer
* Simplify `~Element` destructor

CI status:

* [passes on jenkins trusty](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/sdformat/job/sdformat-any-devel-trusty-amd64/18/)
* [passes on drone](https://drone.io/bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/945)

psutil isn't installed for the homebrew or windows jenkins jobs, though the test passes on my mac laptop
summary.html:
@eltehupkes reported a memory leak in the sdf::Element class in #104 with an example program. I converted his example to a gtest, and I tried something new for measuring memory usage. In gazebo, we have some platform-specific code for getting memory usage on Linux and OS X, but I decided to try using the python psutil module, which is a cross-platform way to get system statistics, like memory usage.

To fix the memory leak, I used a weak pointer. I checked API/ABI and it is fine.

A brief summary of the changes:

  • Use find_package to look for python in order to run the check_test_ran.py script (similar to ign-math pull request 62)
  • Find python module psutil to get memory info, using a cmake function copied from catkin
  • Add memory leak test that uses python psutil
  • Fix memory leak with weak pointer
  • Simplify ~Element destructor

CI status:

  • passes on jenkins trusty
  • passes on drone

psutil isn't installed for the homebrew or windows jenkins jobs, though the test passes on my mac laptop

values.description:
specification based on [this gazebo design document](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo_design/pull-requests/23/sdf_reference_geometry/diff)

Updated all `pose` description with a new `frame` attribute that specifies the frame that the pose is defined in.

should be backward compatible

values.description:
Update to SDF 1.6. This is because the `<imu> <noise>` needs to change. 

* All the `.sdf` files are the same as in 1.5, except for `imu.sdf`.
* A `1_5.convert` script was added
* The `Converter` was updated to handle the complex imu conversion required.
* A test for the IMU conversion was added.
values.title: sdf 1.6

summary.raw:
Update to SDF 1.6. This is because the `<imu> <noise>` needs to change. 

* All the `.sdf` files are the same as in 1.5, except for `imu.sdf`.
* A `1_5.convert` script was added
* The `Converter` was updated to handle the complex imu conversion required.
* A test for the IMU conversion was added.
summary.html:
Update to SDF 1.6. This is because the <imu> <noise> needs to change.

  • All the .sdf files are the same as in 1.5, except for imu.sdf.
  • A 1_5.convert script was added
  • The Converter was updated to handle the complex imu conversion required.
  • A test for the IMU conversion was added.

values.description:
The converter script was missing a closing comment. Updated the converter test, which conveniently skipped over the commented out section.

Also removed a few "cerr" statements that would spam the console needlessly.

values.description:
Useful for simulating realistic cameras and also for emulating projectors as cameras \(for projection mapping\).

Tested in ROS Melodic in Ubuntu 18.04.

Related with:

* https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/pull-requests/2058/added-camera-intrinsics-fx-fy-cx-cy-s
* https://github.com/ros-simulation/gazebo\_ros\_pkgs/pull/767

values.description:
* Add SDFORMAT_RUN_VALGRIND_TESTS CMake option to run tests with Valgrind
* Fix memory leak in Console class
* Fix memory leak in URDF parser

I was trying to debug a non-determinist bug in https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/pull-requests/1721/cache-joint-force-torque-for-ode-and-dart/diff , and I wanted to make sure there was no use of not initialized memory in the tests using Valgrind. Unfortunately the Valgrind output was not clean, mainly for some errors in the libraries used by Gazebo. This PR cleans the `sdformat` related Valgrind errors. 

To facilitate debug of memory issues, a `SDFORMAT_RUN_VALGRIND_TESTS` CMake option was added (default value set to OFF) to automatically run all the tests under Valgrind, and to reported a failed test if Valgrind detects some memory-related errors. This can be removed from the PR, but I found it quite useful in the debug and so I guess it could be also useful in the future.
values.title: Fix memory leaks

summary.raw:
* Add SDFORMAT_RUN_VALGRIND_TESTS CMake option to run tests with Valgrind
* Fix memory leak in Console class
* Fix memory leak in URDF parser

I was trying to debug a non-determinist bug in https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/pull-requests/1721/cache-joint-force-torque-for-ode-and-dart/diff , and I wanted to make sure there was no use of not initialized memory in the tests using Valgrind. Unfortunately the Valgrind output was not clean, mainly for some errors in the libraries used by Gazebo. This PR cleans the `sdformat` related Valgrind errors. 

To facilitate debug of memory issues, a `SDFORMAT_RUN_VALGRIND_TESTS` CMake option was added (default value set to OFF) to automatically run all the tests under Valgrind, and to reported a failed test if Valgrind detects some memory-related errors. This can be removed from the PR, but I found it quite useful in the debug and so I guess it could be also useful in the future.
summary.html:
• Add SDFORMAT_RUN_VALGRIND_TESTS CMake option to run tests with Valgrind
  • Fix memory leak in Console class
  • Fix memory leak in URDF parser

I was trying to debug a non-determinist bug in https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/pull-requests/1721/cache-joint-force-torque-for-ode-and-dart/diff , and I wanted to make sure there was no use of not initialized memory in the tests using Valgrind. Unfortunately the Valgrind output was not clean, mainly for some errors in the libraries used by Gazebo. This PR cleans the sdformat related Valgrind errors.

To facilitate debug of memory issues, a SDFORMAT_RUN_VALGRIND_TESTS CMake option was added (default value set to OFF) to automatically run all the tests under Valgrind, and to reported a failed test if Valgrind detects some memory-related errors. This can be removed from the PR, but I found it quite useful in the debug and so I guess it could be also useful in the future.

values.description:
This commit changes the Param.cc parsing of floating point values to always
use the stof family of functions to parse parameters given as hex strings
(e.g. strings starting with 0x or 0X). It removes the special case handling
for hex strings in the parser, and processes all strings using the same logic.
The isHex check is now used to specify the correct numeric base for the integer
conversion functions.

This commit also removes the boost special case in the HexFloat/HexDouble
Param.cc unit tests. Comments around the special case indicated that
boost::lexical_cast is able to handle parsing floats from hex values in boost
versions 1.58.0 and higher.  This appears not to be the case based on
issue #108. The stof family does handle these hex strings properly, so the
revised tests always expect successful parsing. Tests were also added to parse
the hex value 0X2A with a capital X and an arbitrary numerical value.

Tested with gcc 5.3.1 and boost 1.58.0 on Fedora 23.
values.title: Use stof functions to parse hex strings as floating point params

summary.raw:
This commit changes the Param.cc parsing of floating point values to always
use the stof family of functions to parse parameters given as hex strings
(e.g. strings starting with 0x or 0X). It removes the special case handling
for hex strings in the parser, and processes all strings using the same logic.
The isHex check is now used to specify the correct numeric base for the integer
conversion functions.

This commit also removes the boost special case in the HexFloat/HexDouble
Param.cc unit tests. Comments around the special case indicated that
boost::lexical_cast is able to handle parsing floats from hex values in boost
versions 1.58.0 and higher.  This appears not to be the case based on
issue #108. The stof family does handle these hex strings properly, so the
revised tests always expect successful parsing. Tests were also added to parse
the hex value 0X2A with a capital X and an arbitrary numerical value.

Tested with gcc 5.3.1 and boost 1.58.0 on Fedora 23.
summary.html:
This commit changes the Param.cc parsing of floating point values to always use the stof family of functions to parse parameters given as hex strings (e.g. strings starting with 0x or 0X). It removes the special case handling for hex strings in the parser, and processes all strings using the same logic. The isHex check is now used to specify the correct numeric base for the integer conversion functions.

This commit also removes the boost special case in the HexFloat/HexDouble Param.cc unit tests. Comments around the special case indicated that boost::lexical_cast is able to handle parsing floats from hex values in boost versions 1.58.0 and higher. This appears not to be the case based on issue #108. The stof family does handle these hex strings properly, so the revised tests always expect successful parsing. Tests were also added to parse the hex value 0X2A with a capital X and an arbitrary numerical value.

Tested with gcc 5.3.1 and boost 1.58.0 on Fedora 23.
